etymologies: late Middle English (originally as indiscrete in the sense ‘lacking discernment or judgement’): from late Latin indiscretus ‘not separate or distinguishable’ (in medieval Latin ‘careless, indiscreet’), from in- ‘not’ + discretus ‘separate’ (see discreet). Compare with indiscrete

definitions: having, showing, or proceeding from too great a readiness to reveal things that should remain secret or private

examples.text: they have been embarrassed by indiscreet friends

shortDefinitions: having, showing, or proceeding from too great readiness to reveal things that should remain private or secret
